div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.

Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.p:
local and general.
Deutsche Orient Bank.
The Alexandria branch of the Deutsche Orient Bunk has been at work since the 3rd in*t.. and the branch at Cairo will be estab­lished short’y.
Fire at Alexandria.
Fire broke out yesterday in a farniture shop belonging to Mursi Ambar, in the Sonk El Kanto, and was extinguished by the Fire- Bri< ide. The damage has . not yet been estimated.
French Chamber of Commerce.
The December number of the Bulletin of the French Chamber of Commerce of Alex- I audria contaius an analysis of the Financial Adviser’s Note, aud amass of usefal informa­tion on Egypt's financial and commercial progress.
Egyptian Enterprise Co.
On the 15th October M. Toussaint Canerd sold to the Egyptian Enterprise and Develop­ment Co. for £350,00 a quantity of land at Boulac. On Friday last this identical piece of land was rosold by the company for £61.500.
The Municipal Elections.
It will not be iuopportnne to remind those of our readers who are not on the lists of voters for the Alexandria Munioipal elections, that they have only np to the 1st inst. to apply, if ter that date no application for the municipal franchise can be entertained.
In a Few Months.
To obtaiu in a short time a result which formerly often requited long months of study, such is the advantage the Berlitz cJchool offers, which explains its universal success. Berlitz School of Languages : A exandria, 26, Rue de V Eg baa Copte; Cairo 1, Sharia KameL [Advt.] The Kahil Property.
It is announce 1 that Mme Veuve Kahil Pacha rtfuses to sell her property and garden iu the Ismailia quarter of Cairo for L.E. 105,(kO. Some companies have offered even up to L.E. 170,000 in annual payments for this property, but these offers have not been entertained.
Mother and Daughter Asphyxiated,
Ou a ould night, a few days ago, a native womau and her daughter, of Kafr Sakr, went to bed iu a dosed room with a charcoal fire, lu the morning the mother and daughter we e found dead in their beds. The post-mortem examination showed that death was due to suffocation.
Alexandria's Tranquillity.
The celebration of Greek New Year’s Day passed off very quietly. Every precaution had been taken by the Alexandria City Police to cope with any disturbance that might ooour. The guards at each police station throughout the ci y were doubled and mounted polioemen patioiled the streets, but there was not the slightest disturbance. In faot, the tranquillity of the city now-a-days isabsolutely unparalleled. Death of Mr. Stiliano Platidis,
We regret to announce the death of the director cf the Greek Hospital at Alexandria, Mr. Stiliano Platidis, which occurred early on Saturday morning from heart disease. The funeral took place on Saturday afternoon, at 4.30 o’c.ock, and was largely attended by all classes of the Helleuio community of Alexan­dria, by whom the deceased was held in high esteem.
The Kaiser’s Birthday.
Ou the ocoasion of the forty-seventh anni­versary of the birthday of the Kaiser, a grand fete will be given by the German colony at Cairo at 3.30 p.m. at the German school. On the following day there will be a thanksgiving service at 10 a.m. in the German Churoh in the Ismailia quarter, at 11 a.m. a reception at the German Agency, at 7.30 p.m.'a banquet at the Continental Hotel, aud at 9.30 p.m. a fdte at the German Club.
Capture of Noted Murderer.
This morning a Bedouin was brought into Alexandria from Mariout by an escort of the Sudanese polioemen who gn^rdL. over that district. The man is a notorious malefao’or aud some three years ago committed a murder under most atrooious circumstances in the ueighbourhood of Kafr Dawar. He esoaped into the desert and was sentenced in his absence to penal servitude for life. About two years ago he committed another savage murder in Mariout aud again he managed to evade the clutches of the police and was onoe more sen fenced in his absence to penal servitude for life. However, the police kept watch f ir the man aud yesterday he appeared at Amrieh, where he was rec >gnised and captured.
An Excellent Example,
In view of the increase in the oost of living in this country, the excellent example set by Messrs. Walker and Meimaraohi, Ltd., is one which should be extensively followed. The firm have on the occasion of the New Year increased the salaries of their employes by
amounts which in the aggregate totals several hundred pounds. The appreciation that this humanitarian action, which is due to Mr. C. Moimarachi, has met with at the hands of the employees benefited, cannot be better expressed than by reproducing the letter which they have addressed to their popular managing director:—

THE ELECTIONS.
LANCASHIRE’S FREE TRADE VOTE.
( Gazette’s Special Service. )
London, Monday, Jan. 15. The feeling of the country with regard to the elections is unmistakable. It is tbviously tired of seeing Balfour batting and is more inclined to give the other side an innings rather than fight it out on any defiuiteisiue, although Mr. Balfour has been oroshingly defeated. Lanca­shire has undoubtedly again championed the polioy ot free imports, which is not onnataral, considering the present great prosperity of the Lancashire trade

cell.p: A new first olass Liberal paper, “The Tri­bune,” which has been in preparation for some “me, was appropriately issued thia morning.
According to an offioial report published to­day at the Ministry ofthe Interior an explosion which caused some loss of life took place on the night of the 12th inst. at Boulac Dacrour station.

It appears that shortly after 8 p.m. train No. 254 entered the station and an emplo­ye, lifting the tarpaulin which covered an j open truok containing a number of barrels of benzine, discovered that one of thete barrels was on fire. The truck was immediately un- oonpled aud was being shunted on to a siding to enable the lailway officials to extinguish the flames when a series ot explosions took plaoe.
Fifieen men were injured, two of whom have sinoe suooumbed, and the condition of several ot the others is reported to be critical.
An enquiry is being held into the causes of the aocident.
The Connoil of Ministers which met on Saturday morning under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive took the following de­cisions :—

list.item: To transfer the following officials: Mahmond Bey Rasmi, Suh-Moudir of Minieh, to Assouan to replace Ahmed Bey Mustapha, resigned ; Hafez Bey El Kharbontti, Sub-Mondir of As­souan, to be Sub Governor of Ismailia, to re- plaoe All Eff. Gelal el Din, appointed Mamonr of the Public Security section in Gharbieh.
To appoiut Mahmond Pacha Fehmi to be a member of the Superior Council of the Wakfs Administration.

To oonvoke the Ghirgeh provincial coun­cil on the 20th inst. for the eleotion of two of its members and their proxies to form part of the Committee of Appeal in questions referring to the reassessment of taxes.
To approve of the grant of a subvention ofL.E. 3,000 to the Orwat El Woska Sooiety for the construction of an industrial school at Alexandria.

cell.p: Other decisions deal with questions of expropriation, publio buildings, etc., and with the lists of officials recommended for honours by the various State Administrations, which were all approved.

On Friday night Aida was played before a fall and enthusiastic house, whioh was generous in its applause and showed an amazing want of artistic taste in demanding encores at the wrong moment A particularly flagrant instance of this ooourred in the 3rd act,when Amonasro, having hurled his undntifal daughter to the ground, was enoouraged to repeat the perfor­mance by the plaudits of the greater part of the audience and very properly deolined. At other times a pause of a few bars in an aria was utilised by members of the dress oirole to “bis” the soloist. Those who knew the opera better hissed them into silence, but the result­ing din more than once prevented a good piece of orchestral mosio from being properly heard The next musioal reform required in Cairo is the abolition of the “encore” bat we shall never get it

Now for the opera and artistes. Aida opened badly, the artistes were nervous, the audieuce cold till the oousecratiou soene. Henoeforth the singing improved steadily. Signora Lavin as Amueris and Sig. Amato (Amonasro) were really good. Signora Ross (Aida) improved greatly after the first aot bat there seemed to be a certain want of tone in her higher notes. Sig. Nioolaon. (Ramfis) sang with the papal dignity that befitted a high priest of Ra, but

Sig. Langobardi was QDeven—poor at the opening, better in the third act, and rather weak in the fourth, in which he teemed to have overstrained his voice. Pharaoh was rather stiff, while the corps du ballet were positively wooden ; their movements were characterised by a complete absence of grace and their training appeared to have been utterly neglec ted. On the other hand, the chorus was really good and the orchestra highly satisfactory.

The gallery behaved as the gallery does fiction of the knockabout sort. Such perfor mances are amusing in narrative but peculiarly trying in real life. There were no unnecessary delays, nothing, in fact, that could justify a section of the audience in behaving like the habitues of an eighth-rate music hall

The Mahmal reached Snez yesterday at noon by a special traio, whioh was sainted from the fort with 21 gnns. The procession through the principal streets of Suez started at 2.30 p.m. It was exceptionally well organized this year and was headed by H E. the Governor of Snez on hot o’»- ck. The prooession consisted of Cavaby. Infantry, Artillery with field and Maxim guns, and a military band, all of which presented a brilliant aspeot.

Iu spite of the good order maintained, a regrettable inoident occurred while the Mahmal was passing the Italian Consulate On the verandah of the consulate there was a French lady, who, seeing the Holy Carpet for the first time, was endeavouring to take a snapshot of it with her camera. A oonstable, however, on seeing the lady taking a photo, oalled out to her to go into the house, and as the lady did not take any notice of his absurd demands, he began to throw stones at her, thus drawing the attention < f the considerable number of natives following the carpet, who might very possibly have followed his example. Fortunately, the Italian Consol. Mr. Deperais, happened to be on the verandah also at the time, and prompt­ly sent his janissary to take the oonstable’s number, and order him to withdraw, which he did after insulting the consul by shootiog ont "inta min,” eto.
Another photographer who took np his stand rear the station was stoned by the mob.
The Mahmal is leaving Snez to day by the Khedivial steamer Rahmanieh.

div.p:
THE PRINCES’ CASE.
The hearing of the action brought by the Khedivial Princes against the Credit Foncier has been postponed till March 12.

cell.p: H.R.H. Prince Charles William of 8weden and suite, who have been staying for two days at the Cataract Hotel here, have left Assouan for Lnxor, where rooms have been reserved for them at the Luxor Hotel.
His Royal Highness Prinoe Leopold of i Battenberg and suite are expect e I back at the Cataract Hotel on the 15th. inst, where his Royal Highness will stay till the end of the season.

The hotels are now pretty fall, and owing to the delightful weather many tourists are postponingiheir departure. A Sports Committee has been formed at the Cataraot Hotel for the purpose of arranging sports af all kinds,— Gymkhanas, regattas, croquet and tennis tournaments, and also indoor entertainments, sach as dances,theatricals, ooncerts.eto, for the benefit of the visitore. A paper ohase will take plaoe this week and the oommittee announoe from now that the grand annual fanoy dress ball of the Cataraot will be held on the 29th inst. Passengers of the S. S. Rameses the Third are to be invited.

The S.S. Gera and 8tuttgart, belonging to the N.D.L., and chartered by the Russian Government, arrived at Suez this morning fall of Russian prisoners from the Far East. They both entered the Canal in the afternoon.

The hired transport Dnnera, from Hong- Kong, Shanghai and Colombo, is dne to arrive at Snez early to morrow morning honnd to Malta and Southampton with homeward-bonnd troops. ___________________________

The budget of the Wakfs Administration for 1906 shows an increase of L.E. 68,000 in the receipts, which are expeoted to amount to L.E. 384,500, while the expenditure amounts to L.E. 328,675, showing an increase of L.E. 68,509. L.E. 12,000 will be spent on the inorease of the pay of the employes and L E. 15.000 on the creation of an inspectorate— a reform suggested by Harari Pacha’s recent report.
We are asked by the Clerk of the Course to give notioe that the race course will be open for trial gallops on Wednesday morning next, the 17th inst., from six to ten.
The Moss liner Rameses arrived at Liver­pool on Saturday morning.

cell.p: Thomas Fraser Thomson was oharged before Mr. Alban at H.B.M.’s Consular Court, Cairo, on Saturday morning with embezzling I the sum of L E. 267 belonging to Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt), Ltd. The first witness was Mr. Harrison, who stated that he knew accused, who was employed as a cle*k at Messrs. Cook’s engineering works at Boulac, where he had bsen working since Jane. He stated that in consequence of information I received he had taken steps to proseonte aooused. The details of the oase were known to I Mr. Sibhald, Messrs. Cook’s superintending I engineer.

Mr. T. K. Sibbald stated that he had known I aooused for some six months as his chief corresponding olerk. On Friday week he fonnd Thomson missing from the office in the morning and asked Mr. Reynolds, the Assistant I Superintendent, where he was. In oonseqner.ee I of oommunioations reoeived from Mr. Reynolds and a bowab he went down himself to Messrs. I Cook’s dahabeah, where he fonnd aconsed in I bed with all his olothes on and very dronk. I He oonld make no coherent statement. On I the following day aoonsed did not appear and on Monday witness reoeived a wire from Port I Said in whioh aoonsed said he was reonperatiDg 1 and would oome to work on Tuesday. As he did not appear witness oommnnioated with Messrs. CaDgosand Co., oontraotors, and asked them if they h.d reoeived railway polioies for explosives and whether they had paid any snms to Thomson. He fonnd that a cheque on the Anglo-Egyptian Bank had been given to aoonsed in payment of an account and oashed by aooused at the Anglo Egyptian Bank.

Mr. Cangos deposed—with a certain vague­ness as to dates—that the accused came to see him re an order he had given to Me-ww. Cook for detonators and gelignite tor the Fayoum. He oame again with an aooonnt and a oheqne in payment was signed by witness’s partner Kassim Bey Hosni and made ont by witness’s olerk Pericles Kytioaki.

Selim Abassi, oashier of the Anglo Egyptian Bank, Cairo, recollected the aooased’s oalling at the Bank. Aoonsed asked for a cheque made payable to Messrs. Cook. When oheq ies were presented at the bank the usual course followed was to hand the oheque over to tl • acoonntant to see whether the signatory had oredit and the oheqne was then passed on to the oashier for payment. This oheque was made payable to Thos. Cook & 8on or bearer. Witness gave aooused £250 in banknotes, the rest in cash. In answer to a question pat by the aooased, witness stated that the num­bers ot bank notes were never kept. Notes P and cash were given to any persons, even : Barberine servants, presenting cheques that ’ were in good order.

div.p:
DISTURBANCE AT DAMANHOUR.
Oar Damanhonr Correspondent reports that a disturbance took plaoe in that town yester­day, a conflict having arisen between a num­ber of Jews and the natives, on the occasion of the celebration of a Jewish feast. Some hun­dreds of persons took part in the affray, and many were injured in the oonrse of the melde, which might have assumed much more serious proportions, but for the timely interference of the polioe. It appears that the aggressors were the natives, whose attitude was not at all reassnring

cell.p: The Holiness Movement Churoh of Canada held a oonv'-ntion in this town from the 5th to the 7th inst, inclusive, in oonneotion with the dedication of their first ohuroh in Egypt It was largely attended from the opening until the closing service.

The main body cf the new choroh has a seating capacity of abont six hundred, and there is also a gallery accommodating more than two hundred. Every place waa packed fall and numbers had to stand outside.
There were six missionaries present together with a large sbff of native preachers. One of the chief characteristics of the meetings has been prayer,which continues almost unceasingly day and night

Pressure on onr spaoe on Saturday prevented ns from dealing with the social aspect of Friday’s 8kye Meeting at the K. 8. C. grounds, Ghezireh. In spite of its being oue of the smaller meeting* there were many people present, and it was by far the smartest meeting we have seen this season. Among others we noticed :— General Bollock, Sir William Garatin, Hon. L. M. Iddings, Baroness and the Miles de Villebob, Major and Mrs. Herbert Gapt and Mrs. Maclean, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Capt. and Mrs. Bailey. Major and Mrs. Parsons, Major and Mrs. Delavoye, Gapt. and Mrs. Rome, Goles Pacha, Mrs. and the Misses Co'es, Dr. and Mrs. Armstrong, Dr. and Mrs. Nolan, Mr. and Mrs. Stoat, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Hewitt, Mr. Allan Jo-eph and Miss Joseph, Mrs. French, Omar Bey Saltan, Iahak Bey Hussein, the Hon. G. Yorke, Mr. Garter Wilson, Major Herbert, Gol. Aylmer, Mr. Dicey, Mr. Foreatier-Walker, Mr. Satow, Mr. Reid, Capt. Gillson, Mr. A. L. Moberlev, Mr. Garter Wil8nn, Mr. Rnmbold^ Mr. Oroville, and Gapt Bartlett.

8ir Augustus and Lady Hemming were there, the latter in dark bine with lace appliance, while Miss Hemming was in a cream aoooraion- pleated skirt and pretty lace-trimmed blouse. Gapt and Mrs. Morgan were also present, Mrs. Morgan in a lovely Parisian frock of laoe with narrow applications of pale grey doth set as flounoes on the skirt, and composing the smart little coatee and three-oorned nat. Mrs. Wynne was in white olotb, inset with ooarse ! net and trimmed with silk braid, lines of gnaging drawing the fulness of the back into the waist. Her nat of felt had the brim lined with fine straw and was tilted high on one Bide bv a caohpeigne of brown velvet and adorned

on the other side by sweeping plames. Mrs. Roylewasin dark bine, the corsage slashed with mnoh laoe, and Mrs. Maclean was in white oloth, the pleata of both bolero and skirt fastened down by small buttons, buttons also forming the trimming at the hem of the skirt and on the elbow sleeves. The Miles de Villebois were in dark blue and wore black hats, and Mme. de Martino was gowned iu brown and had a couple of peacock s feathers in her toque. A report is current in Berlin financial circles which ought to be well informed that farther negotiations between the Hamburg-Amerika and North German Lloyd Steamship Companies have brought a fusion of the two undertakings considerably nearer realization. Although the lisped was settled a fortnight so, forth t conferences between Herr Ballin and Herr Wiegand took place towards the end of last week, and it is said that the question of amalgamation was disused in detail.

It is farther stated that these two gentlemen drew up the outlines of a definite scheme for presentation to the general meeting of their respective companies. It is impossible to obtain definite particulars of what has passed, owing to the fact that both companies persistently re­fuse all information. It is certain, however, that one or two of the leading financial houses in Berlin have made extensive purchases of the shares of both the Hambarg and the Bremen companies in anticipation of amal­gamation, which would probably result in considerable financial gain to the shareholders of both.

It is also stated the contracts which the North German Lloyd recently confounded with the Russian Government for the transport of troops from Vladivostok to Odessa contained a clause providing for the possibility of fusion.

cell.p: TENDERS are hereby invited for new Con­tracts for the supply to Frosh Beef, Mutton Vegetables, Soft Bread, and Water to His Majesty’s Ships at Port Said and Suez, for twelve months from 1st April 1905.
Each artiole should be tendered for separate­ly, but the tenders for all the artioles offered by any petiolar firm m rat be placed on the same form.
Prices should be quoted in English currency

Forms of Application can be obtained from the Navy Agent, British Consulate, Port Said to whom tenders should be sent in duplicate, in sealed envelope, in time to be received not later than the 31st January 1906.

cell.p: MOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the H ANNUAL ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the Company, adjourned from the 21st December, 1905, will be held in Hall No. 43, Winchester Hones, Old Broad Street, in the City of London, on Tuesday, 30th January, 1906, at 3 p.m. o’olock precisely, for the purpose of receiving the Directors’ Report and Balance Sheet for the period ended 30th September, 1905, electing Directors in the place of the three retiring by rotation, appoint­ing Auditors for the ensuing year and fixing their remuneration, declaring a Dividend, and transacting the Ordinary General Business to the Company, and also for the purpose of considering and, if thought fit, passing the following Resolution then intended to be pro­posed, that is to say

That, in pursuance of Article 44 of the Statutes of the Metropolitan and Cairo-Helaman Railway, and in view of the recommendation of the Conaeil d’Admi- nitration, a sum of L.E. 2412.780 out of the profits of the Metropolitan and Cairo-Helaman Railway for the year ending 31st December, 1904, be placed to special Reserve Fund.
Dividend Warrants will be Issued on the 2nd February, 1906.

A few days ago we reviewed M. A. Grenville’s recently publicized work “New Egypt” This lively book lends itself to extracts, which will give on readers some idea of the excellence of its contents.
Here is a description of some aspects of Cairo in the season, which in some persons* opinion may justify the appellation of “Grave of the Sun" which has been bestowed on the gay capital of Egypt

There is something in the air of Egypt, a something which seems to excite every one, more or less, which almost maddens certain natures, especially of the weaker sex, and which seems to drive them to continuous pursuit of all the pleasures of the senses. The result is that all the world flirts, and the most extraordinary stories ran the round of the hotels. Young girt* seem to have a very pronounced weakness for the Egyptian, a weakness which some­times seems to lead to an entire absence of any idea of "les consonances.” A young Egyptian glib of tongue and an excellent danger one said to me :

*' I assure yon I could write a volume of adventures which is the way of □s young Egyptians in winter’, and the way in which these young girls throw themselves at one, beads world astonish the world. Several of ns, for sport, formed a society which we called the ‘tetras- siers,’ because we ‘did* the terraces of the various hotels, bat it was no use, we had to GiveItUp ; no constitution could stand the success which covered one efforts."

But the adventures of these young blades pale before those of the dragomans, these splendid men, built like Hercules, strong as horses, and so picturesque in their native costume. Their duty is to serve as guide and interpreter, to organize everything for their masters, excursions and parties of all sorts. Like the Arabs, the Egyptians and all the Orientals from the lowest to the highest, the dragomans are mad where a European or an American woman ii concerned. For them they represent the acme of sexual attraction, and. at least, for the lowest class, age and looks are quite unimportant. One can then perhaps understand, if not forgive, the woman whose looks have suffered from the passing of the years, or who, born with a lack of the fatal gift, baa lingered long in the old shades of neglect, se:i;ng e'gerly the opportunity to besom-ng an object 01 adoration, in engaging an Egyptian drago­man.
Then follow some curious stories. The tale of the young American girl and the "muastiquaire” is in fact far too risqué for our chaste columns.
Elsewhere the author remarks " In this continual round of fifties and

pleasures of dinners, balls, and suppers, all the world of Cairo and his wife amuse them­selves and flirt As to this flirtation, I am twelvefold that in no other city in the world (does it play so large a part; and yet it seems, I was not there at the proper time. I left too soon. Winter, it seems, is nothing coppered with spring, when, as we know, a young man’s fancy lightly torn?....

" 1 am leaving Cairo,” a friend of mine wrote me in April, a lady whom one only not describe as a prude, “I am leaving Cairo, for I can not stand any longer the sight of these couples, who, now that the hot weather has come, seem to have lost all notion of les convening*a.”

Well, hombre Amie, we most not be too hard on poor Cairo. Spring is the great sinner in all lands ; and if he seems some­what more alive there than elsewhere, is it his fault, is it not rather the fault of the climate and sun 1

Apropos of the wealthy Boropean and Izvantine Society in Cairo, our author says:— The origin of many of there fortunes, though not unknown or even forgotten, is wisely bidden by a thick veil, which old residents occasionally amuse themselves by lifting for the entertainment of curious persons like myself. Then it is that they tickle your ears with stories of which the heroes, bearers of names well known and respected, period of their titles and decoration«, strong in their relationships and friends, appear in the early stage, of their careers as nothing more or less than

Bot after all, what does it matter t The 0-dore, those who have struggled and suc­ceeded at a time when every one robbed ®ore or less, are to-day veiy old. To­morrow they will have gone, and another generation, well brought op, high'y educat­ed, elegant, fashionable to tbe tips of their fingers, will not be responsible for the kind of money which their fathers need. Don't let us dig too deep. Out of a dunghill a rose may grow and many another beautiful thing. And besides, as every one knows, money has no smell, and less even in Egypt
77,0 Ahuandrlan Here is his description of the typical

For several years the mania for speoola- tion seems to have attacked the whole popnlai.on, and the stock exchange at Alex­andria is, as it were, the heart of the body politic, fell of lif8i of hopes Md ffargi
B-’i."S’,E?ypt" h* A B- d# O»"Ulo On sal. at 1 ocholsr ■ Library, Alexandria. j

where every one, large and small, rich or poor, strong or weak, meets on common jjTonnd. Cotton, its rise or fall, that is the predominant thought in the minds of all those men amongst whom are so many familiar faces.

Indeed, after nine months’ scraping and hoarding, these good Alexandrians troop across to Paris and the best known wa­tering-places on the continent, to disgorge in the remaining three months their accumul­ated gains.

AU have the look of men well pleased with the world, and all explain themselves thus, “My dear fellow, on sin less is A.I. Egypt has entered on an era of prosperity hardly credible. We are making money hand over fist, every one is in the swim. Yon will see for yourself, from one end of Egypt to the other yon will hoar the same story. The Government has been able to reduce taxation and increase the salaries of its employees, big and little. The golden ago has arrived J"

Can this be possible 1 can it be that, whilst in Europe and America every one cries poverty, there is only prosperity here in this land of Egypt, which scarcely twenty years ago was in a state of bankruptcy and, strange as it may each, not one of these men will speak to yon of Egypt, of its history, of its artistic treasures, not one of them will advise yon to visit a museum, a monument or a park.

The Stock Exchange and cotton, these are the be-all and end-all of existence. If by chance they do advise yon to go the theatre, it will not be because there is some­thing particularly good to be seen, but simply because ‘ X receives £4,000 for three performances, and that the stones and jewels in the hair or round the neck9 of the dl<S- gantes represent a sum of £10,000,000 sterling

When he talks cotton or diamonds, your Alexandrian is a bit of a braggart In a word, his head is a money-box, and his heart a purse, and they are both crammed to repletion with banknotes. All the same he is a good fellow, pleasant, hospitable and generous. If he has the faults of the confirm­ed gambler he has also his good qualities.

As to his batter-half, it is difficult to judge. Admiration has pet haps blinded me, for the “Alexandrine" is so pretty, so elegant and so chic, that criticism is quite disarmed. One would have to travel far to find a town where there are so many young women whore good looks and perfect elegance con­tinually charm the eye. It may be said, of course, that they are shallow, that their dresses, their jewels, and especially their flirtations are of more interest to them than the graver questions of life; but what does that matter when they are so charming, and so deliciously feminine! Certainly, we are far from the time when in Alexandria there was a famine of femininity either d'un monde on de Van tre.

The above well-known rivals met on Thurs.- day evening at Kara el-Nil barrack, to decide who ahold enter the second round of the above competition. Both teams hold a good reputa­tion. It will be remembered Company scorned a runners-up position in the football tourna­ment They possess the pond record of having beaten the regimen tai team at one time in India. Both elevens have been going “great guns” end were determined to win. The ground was in the pink of condition and a hot sixty minutes was in store for those who lined the ropes at the appointed time for starting. The ground was well packed. Thera were about 1,600 spec­tators present when tbe referee's whistle announced time for hostilities to someone. Appended are the teams : P. Company—goal, Collins ; backs, Duffy and Page; halves, Har- binson, Walker, and Smyth ; forwards, Peroy, Bradshaw, Collins, Trsc-y. and Boy Armstrong. G.Compsny—Goal, McCaffery; backs,Millarand Bothwell; halves, Dugan, Lyons, and Patterson; forwards, Datton, Garret, HiggiusoD, MitoheU, and Greer.

F. Company started minus Templeton, who was on the sick list, Traeey filling the vsoanoy. Collins started the ball a-rolling and play was at once taken towards McCaffery, but Bothwell cleared at a rational moment. Not to be denied the Greens still pressed bat the ball found touch font times in succession. A melee near goal ended in a corner which proved unproductive. G Company now found their feet, Greer making good headway, bnt Duffy came to the rescue and play was in a trio transferred towards McCaffery when Percy had hard lines, his final shot missing, the post by a hair’s-breadth. On the kick off Lyons got pos­session and gave to Dutton, but the latter dallied on the ball too long and a ohanoe was lost Midfield play now followed and a free kiok relieved matters. This let G Company away, Higginson showing fins form and giving his wing men some splendid opportunities, but Duffy and Company were in splendid form and repelled all attacks. At this stage the excite­ment was intense, each team doing their utmost. F Company now took play in hand and Walker was seen to advantage The new recruit slipped in a daisy cutter and McCaffery just managed to save the ball finding tough.

Play became faster and Walker in attempting to score struck the crossbar which shook the ball, rebounding on to the toe of one of the Greens, who sent in a fact shot, MoCsffeiy saving weakly, with the result that Peroy walked the ball Olean into the net for the Greeaahirts after twenty minutes’ play, amid tremendous cheers.

On ransoming, G Company got away in fine style but Pace octitol Garret and sent strongly np the field, where Tracey got the ball, but Patterson robbed and play was transferred, when Collins came in for a lively time. He however saved marvelously but had to acknowledge defeat at the hands of H:gginson. Amidst deafening cheers midfield play now followed, but nothing of importance occurred np to half-time, the sore standing :
F. Company, I goal, G Company, 1 goal.

The second moiety was resumed and the green, harts got going in fine style until free kick against Tracey spoilt a golden oppor­tunity. Play however remained in midfield, where Collins appealed to the referee for being foaled twice in concession, but no notice was taken. Garret and Datton were combining well and the latter centered well Mitchell receiving sent strongly in to Collins, who saved in a brilliant manner. Still the stripes hovered around Collins, but all to no purpose as that custodian was in fine form. Good play by Smyth resulted in Armstrong getting on a single-handed ran, but his shot went behind. Neither team only claim any advantage, each goal being visited in torn, and the backs on each side being very stubborn. Tracey now got a good orange to add to the score, hot be fell in attempting to shoot Both seta ol forwards were showing good form. F Company now got down per Peroy, who sent well in, but Millar relieved, the ball finding touch. The referee’s ruling of that game seemed most nonhair to both teams. The game rough for a while and G Company’s goal had a very narrow escape, splendid play by Millar averting disaster. The pace was now very last, and each goal was visited with­out remit Doffy received a great cheer for taking the ball from the toe of Dugan and panting well down the field, where some ex- outing play took place amend McCaffery, who saved at the expense ‘of a corner. This was wall taken by Armstrong, but Lyons re­lieved and G Company were seen to advan­tage, Greer getting away on a good ran, bat be event behind. On resuming Collins and Bradshaw combining well got close to Mc­Caffery, but Bothwell robbed Collins when in the act of shooting, the ball finding tonos. From the throw in Armstrong got on a singlehanded run and dodging a couple of opponents sent in a low, swift shot which struck the side to the post and rebounded into the net. but to the dissatisfied supporters of F Company the referee disallowed the goal and gave a corner. Tibia was cleared by Millar and G Company's forwards got a-going, bnt Page robbed in the nook of time. Play from this to the end was very exoiting, but neither team oonld add to their soore, and the long whistle sonnded shortly after for full time, leaving the game a draw and to be replayed at a future date

This afternoon the Port Said Football Club played a return match with a team from the H. M. S Diana, now stationed at Port Said. From the start the Diana forwards showed their superiority over on forwards in passing and quickness and fond on weakest spot, namely, our halves. In the first half the “boys in bine" had most of the attacking to do, and s only the wonderful play of Williams at fall back which kept the ball from the net However, just before half time the Diana snored a goal, which was well deserved, after seem very good play. 8oon after the restart half time was scored. Up to now the home halves had been giving a very poor amount of themselves and everybody was disappointed in the forwards, with the exception of Gun­nery, who was playing a really splendid game. In the second half things were a little more even, but still the Diana had the beat ot the game and more than one just missed the goal. From a corner for the Diana, Gunnery got away, and passed mail after man on hi* own, and after running the length of the field scored a goal with a wonderfully good shot This was without doubt the ran of tbe game and Mr. Gannery is to be congratulated on his fine ran. It is hardly worth while saying anything about the remainder of the game as it consisted mainly of foals, although the Diana scored another goal, and thereby won the math by 9 to 1.

row.cell: As the outcome of the accident on the Great Eastern Railway (England), on 1st September last, in which it will be remembered ten people were killed and about twenty injured, and in whioh a carriage lighted by gas took fire immediately after the accident, the Great Eastern Railway Company have decided, wo are informed, to equip all their new main line rolling stoke in the antra with Stone's System of Electric Lighting instead of gas as here­tofore.

On sait que le droit proportionnel sur les mutations immobilières qui était de S % a été réduit à 2 %, depuis le 1er Janvier de l’année dernière Or, les reoettes non seulement n'ont subi, à la suite de ostte réduction, aucune di­minution, mais elles aoonsent une plus-valno sur celles de l’année dernière.
C’est là encore une preuve éclatante qu'à chaque réluotion de droit ou d’impôt en Egypte correspond inévitablement une plus- value importante dans les recettes totales.

Le Cercle Belge d’Alexandrie a tenu samedi soir dans son local de la Rne Chérif Pach», une réoeption présidée par Mr. Robyns de Sohneidauer, Gérant du Consulat de Belgique, en l’honneur du Commandant du Steamer belge “Hainaut" et de ses officiers, qui ont, le 21 novembre dernior, bien que leur navire fût à peu près désemparé, héroïquemeni sauvé les 24 hommes de l'équipage du vapeur anglais "Saint Bernard'* prêt à sombrer dans le Golfe de G.s- oogne.

Après un disoonrs de M. Moufront, Prési­dent du Cerole, le Capitaine Van Schoonbeeke a pris la parole pour remercier le Cerole de son aooneil, puis le Consul do Belgique a prononcé on petit speecb faisant ressortir la bravoure des marins du -'Hainaut".

Le profit de oette année a été de £14,409 rentre £992 pour l'année précédante. Cet ao- oroissement exceptionnel des béuéfioes a été déterminé par plusieurs oausaa, notamment par b marge onteaue entre le ooût da ooton brnt et le prix de vente des prodaits de b Sooiété ; par b ré J notion oonsidérabb des fais de ma- nubotare, par 1a benno marche et b surcroît de prodnotion des moalins.

Aaoane dépréciation n’a été insorite pour le matériel et b machinerie, mais il y a lien de tenir oompte que b plus-value considérable acquise par le terrain de b Compagnie à Bon- lac oompense largement, pour b passé et l'ave- lir, tonte dépréciation qui a pu on qui pour­rait se produire snr le reste de b propriété de b Société.
La qualité des produits de b Société a été grandement améliorée. Soi marchandises sont en demande creusante et ae vendent à de très bons prix.
Somme tonte, b Compagnie a traversé b période oritique de son existence, et l’avenir de l’entreprise s’annonoemaintenant sons les meil­leurs anspioee.
Loi cours des ootons sont en légère baisse d’Amér.qoe. Le Mai a perdu 4 points et l'Oo- tobre 1 point Le disponible est resté invarié à 1180.
Les arrivages ont été de 95,000 balles oontre 27,000.
Le marché de Liverpool est également plus faible.
Ou nous éorit d’Alexandrie en date d’hier :

“Le marché a été oaline a l’ouverture par suito de la faiblesse de l'Amérioaio. Le Mars a déonté a 15 21/32 et est resté à oe prix, aohe* tenrs, jusqu'à l’arrivée de l’onvertorede Liver­pool annonçant 9 pointa de baisse. A oe mo­ment plusieurs petits spéculateurs baisaiers, voubnt se oouvrir, se sont mû à vendre pour oasser les oonrs ; mais, l'apercevant dn stra­tagème, les haussiers ont ramassé toat oe qai se présentait snr le marché, et b dérenvert, effrayé, a oommenoé à se oouvrir. Aussi bien de 14 21/32 on a monté en dix minutes à 15 27/32. Les haussiers avaient bit oironler le croit qu’il s'était formé un syndioat à b hausse. Cette rumeur ayan été reounuue busse, b marché a fléchi oet après-midi jusqa’à 15 3/1." loi, oe matin, le Mars a ouvert à 15 18/16
Les Bourses do Caire et d'Alexandrie étant fermées lundi prochain, à l’oooaaion des fêtes du Nouvel An vieax style, notre ciroalaire ne paraîtra pas oe jour-là.

MM. H. de Vries et Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent de l’exéoation de tires ordres de Bonne (valeare et marchandises) snr les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, An­vers, Liverpool et New-York. La Ciroalaire quotidienne de b maison est envoyée snr demande.

row.cell: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound.

cell.p: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE has much pleasure iii presenting to its subscribers the accompany­ing description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them us accurately and concisely ns possible, and it will Ira, found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the rented home there are several things to lie considered Io begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which •—u may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which yon leave Egypt, for Cairo in January j may be a little warner than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm aa Sicily, hut in March i it will be warner than Rome, and more unit- ' firmly warm than many other places in Euroiic j Many people leave Egypt far too early in the | year, for as a rule the weather in April and 1 May is perfect. The warmest place to go the on leaving Egypt is Sicily.
I Some will want the take into consideration j the number of days to be spent not seen, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time oc­cupied on each of the various routes between
I Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
T’lio long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 1-1 days. The short ones are as follows ;—
Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi 3 days
Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles 5 „ Alexandria to Venice and Trieste... 4 „

The steamers, of the P. & 0. North German Lloyd, Orient and Missileries Maritime* are the largest The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronized by travelers to Egypt
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, tlio shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 j hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papa Yanni, Prince, and Westcott lines ol steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. & 0. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages te any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isai” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian
mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the “Perry boats,” having been specially built to canny the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the tram waiting at .Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It lies complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on hoard, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

cell.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Plorio- natation Co.'s steamers which leave Alex- indri weekly for MESSINA, where ono takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charm­ing and popular places on the island. Giardini is 'lie station at which to alight end the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Crock, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in u.c. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain —his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found In this fine city. The Palatzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of 8. Giecaenia aegli Ereniti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit
The fine steamers of the North German
Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days
NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from

Palermo by the Florio-Rebating Co.’s steam­ers, which leave daily- One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay— Casts Lamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive tool will take you on to Capri.
From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at ■ least one week to visiting the many historical t and interesting portions of the Eternal City,
, whose charms and beauties are too well-known J to need comment here.

' Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the j churches and galleries are of absorbing inte­rest, whilst the local promenades and excur­sions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable nromenado in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one ol tlie finest walks in Europe, opened 85 years ago, goes winding up through tho hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that te FaZlom- brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog­wheel railway to Salttno. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most [ striking panoramas are unfolded to view, j PISA is easily reached from Florence in ' about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one , night should If possible be made, in order t< enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and or ' the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is e very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reason and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.
in painting by an Exbibitorat theSalon. picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with
the record of having one of the lowest
death averages of European cities ar phenomenally equable emirate—war winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy s most an- event nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and I paintings, ore a constant delight to thousands of travelers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly viliorated medie­val churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and tho in­comparable Campo Santo filled with its won­derful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail

MILAN is a good center lord Northern Italy before making the tour of the. Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its licentious windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monu­mental cemetery ore also worth a visit

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAG- > GIORE, a renowned health resort on account ; of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-horn you are at Salsomaggiore.

VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and vof there is the sound of life at every torn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea­port The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no bills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Cam­paniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the nor of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny,
is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other owns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming' spot; then ooze Tresnexxo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bdlaggio opposite. The walk from Tretnesto along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Rorlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-on-
Swituerland, the heart of Europe, has I described as “A cluster of delights grandeurs.”

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-holf hours. It has a populatien of 10,000 people and is charm­ingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian soenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Capture and M. Generoeo.

LOCARNO may be reached by nil from Bellin zona in forty minutes. Thai pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interest­ing paintings, “Entombment,” by Ciera, and The Flight into Egypt," by Brumation.
LUCERNB.—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Trig and Pilates and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The LUe o/Lucerne abounds m dishful excursions, those to the Riga, Pilatus, Burgan- stoic and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing Scenery on the trip from juicers to Fluellin is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the moat beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Binned to Fluellin runs the famous Accent ratee. .’

that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansted and from Stansted it is about I hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titles, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santi’s to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND.—INTER­LAKEN a favorite summer resort and the best center for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the However , a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous .waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbach and Staubboch. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Sdtynige Platte are sights not to *“

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,600 ft above the on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent finery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in 8ummer and Winter.

div.p:
GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egjqit aa it is so easily reached from Alex­andria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khediviai Mail, Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co. *
If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be presen* at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megan for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few davsin CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had
